We count on residents to actively support youth mentorship, expanded opportunities for those in need, officer recruiting, and community-oriented policing. Everyone can do something to help keep our city safe.

We remain committed to the Group Violence Intervention and other measures that have made a big difference in keeping levels of violent crime here so much lower than when I was a child. But this is not just a law enforcement or government issue.

State and federal government will not come save us. In the absence of federal support for real reform, or common-sense gun safety policies at the state level, it falls to us as a community to continue driving down levels of gun violence through local action.
Last night, January 2nd, brought the year’s first gun violence injury in South Bend. 2018 shootings were down from 2017. We MUST force violence down further in 2019.

As a South Bend resident and as a voter, I will be eager to see candidates step forward who recognize the challenge ahead and care about continuing to transform our city’s future.
I am inexpressibly grateful to all who have given me this chance to help guide South Bend’s extraordinary comeback in this decade.

I also know this is not a job to hold forever, and it is time to give new leadership a chance to lead our city forward. My time in office here will end at the end of 2019, and I will not seek a third term.
Serving South Bend has been the great honor of my life and I’m looking forward to more good work in the remaining year of my current term.

column5: By a margin of many millions, Americans called for change--and we are beginning, but only beginning, to see it descend on Washington. The people can't be denied forever.
Yes, we are a republic--a democratic one. If we care about democracy, then we will always pay attention to the will of the people expressed by the majority of American voters.
It is the overall will of the American electorate. It didn't get its way altogether, but it's how the House came back into balance even in the face of nakedly manipulated districts.
Lots of frantic arm-waving on Twitter about how there's no such thing as a House/Senate popular vote. You bet there is, and it matters--that's why they're denying it so hard.
Remarkable gains for just two years, especially in the face of gerrymandering. But there are mountains yet to climb. https://t.co/S5qDaQBnry
We just made our government more Democratic. The next test will be whether we can make it more democratic.
That’s a #SouthBend November daybreak. https://t.co/AvzVRufRHe

From the patriots who took the beach at Normandy, to the patriots who crossed the bridge at Selma, our right to vote was paid for dearly by heroes on whose shoulders we now stand.

On #ElectionDay, I think about the Afghans I saw with their dyed fingers, risking their lives to cast a ballot. And I think of the Americans I served with and those who went before us, so that you and I can enjoy the right to vote and the power that it represents.

Democracy matters. Each time America grew more democratic, we became better. If we begin to become less so, we will become worse, and worse off.
Right around now, someone will point out that we are republic. Sure. But if we are not a democratic one, then what is the American experiment even about?
Senators representing a minority of Americans will confirm a nominee most Americans oppose, put forward by a president most Americans voted against. Democracy demands better. https://t.co/Rdp8NwJwWz

column5:
Nothing makes America look small quite like a president complaining of being “abused for decades”... by Canada. 

Yet nothing makes us look bigger quite like two other presidents’ words today at the National Cathedral.

column5: This could become as important politically as it already is economically. https://t.co/7NxHMBPgnM
For the rest: hopefully you were there in the trenches with us when we were confronting his worst policies here in Indiana. There will be more where that came from.

I often fought and disagreed with him. I also think certain patterns have arisen in his behavior since he became VP that are new and different from how he acted before. Subtlety isn't popular here on Twitter, but I think it's important to study these changes over time.

Many people here can't get their heads around the idea that someone could be homophobic, fanatical, and wrong, make terrible decisions, and also be sincere. Did he make horrible policy on HIV and many other matters? Yes. Did it destroy lives? Yes. Was it sincere? Yes.

For some reason this tweet is recirculating now. It was off, but I'm not deleting it because I don't believe in trying to erase prior (mis)statements. A couple thoughts for those who are jumping on this again...

South Bend's (and America's) drop in violence compared to the 1990s didn't just happen on its own. It took sustained community action. Reversing the current trend toward younger victims will require the same. We must study what works and build on it. And everyone has a role.
If you are equally heartbroken by reports of gun violence, ask how you can be part of the solution. Mentor. Volunteer. Participate. Visit. Learn. Help.

But more than any one policy or program, we need community and cultural answers. All of us can help to break the cycles of isolation of the most at-risk (half a percent or so) young people who account for nearly all gun violence.

Even in a state that restricts us from locally enacting popular, constitutional, and evidence-based policies related to access to guns, we can (and do) act at the local level, from civilian street outreach to enforcement actions against violent groups.

We have worked to address violence through every known means, from law enforcement coordination to mentorship and employment support. Yet amid the routine statistical ups and downs, there is more and more heartbreak involving teenagers.
All gun violence is infuriating, but there is a deeper anguish when it involves young people. Our entire community has a role to play in breaking cycles of violence for those most at risk.

column5: @HicksCBER @nate3carp @ibdsh Buh? At a dataset level the correlation is unbelievably strong: https://t.co/zGqOcDdwv8

@HicksCBER @ibdsh @sothenkatiesays Are you aware of any studies that refute (or otherwise evaluate) the strong intuition that CT's remarkable drop in gun violence after 2012 had to do with the impact of the state's policy changes?

@HicksCBER @nate3carp @ibdsh The research shows powerfully clear patterns of correlation. As for causation, we'd know more if Congress hadn't banned federal research on the topic, no?
https://t.co/zGqOcDv7TI

Kennedy, citing Bratton: Our first principle needs to be “do no harm.” We have now learned how the wrong kind of policing, done in the wrong way, can drive cooperation down and crime up.
Kennedy: We speak of “troubled” or “high risk” communities. In truth they are fundamentally healthy except for tiny numbers of people with astronomically high risk
Typically one half of one percent of people, or less, in a given jurisdiction are causing most of the violence
Kennedy: people have come to realize that a very, very small number of dangerous people are behind most violent crimes in all of our communities

Yes, it's harder to do if you're honest and not cynical. But it can be done. We must pay more attention to digital; doors, phones, broadcast and mail are no longer the whole picture. https://t.co/mr2DYUEQld
@Jjuliaann I'll check - does @SouthBend311 have a ticket on this?

Like most competitive fields, it may be easier for the cynical, for those who cheat and resort to trickery. But we do not have to emulate them to outrun them. We just have to be smarter than we've been before in the digital space.
Much will depend on whether Democrats get better at social media as a tool for persuasion and for gathering feedback.
Our side thought it had mastered digital because we pioneered digital tools for organizing and for fundraising. But persuasion is another matter.

column5: RT @southbendpolice: If you see a road that is still blocked off but looks dry, do NOT go around barriers. The road may be dry, but the wat…
Mayor's Night Out will take place as planned this evening at Dickinson School at 5:30 p.m. - I'll be there to talk one-on-one with residents on any issue. See you there!
Several roads remain flooded and others may be compromised. Drivers who ignore closure barriers will be ticketed. Be smart and drive safe!
River levels are at 12.5 feet, slightly down from overnight peak. We are assessing damage which is extensive, and river will remain flooded for several days.

@iolantherosa Obviously. But if you do, a community is there to hold you accountable.
If Donald Trump wants to be America's mayor, let him join me for a day in South Bend and see how a mayor and city get stuff done together.
Above all, a mayor calls a city to its highest values, and brings out the best in people.
A mayor assumes responsibility for what's happening in the city, good and bad. A mayor cannot afford to specialize in allocating blame.
A mayor knows her highest responsibility is to unite her constituents, and does not pit them against each other.
Contrary to the article, the Carrier stunt would never fly for a mayor, because people live here and would hold you accountable.
A mayor doesn't insult women. For one thing, he or she will run into their spouses or parents somewhere in town.
A mayor cannot dismiss or ignore the press, because the press is made of people who live in the same community.
A mayor cannot possibly traffic in alternative facts, because the facts are everywhere.
A mayor worries less about credit and blame, more about results. A mayor picks up the trash, plows the snow, fills holes in the road.
He has nothing resembling a "mayoral core." If he did, he'd be more concerned with solving problems. A mayor knows it's not all about him.
Trump is nothing like an American mayor, not a modern one anyway. Certainly not a good one.
This piece completely misses what it means to be a mayor. The president is nothing like a mayor, and that's too bad. https://t.co/G2kDr7tSsW
